text:
Iridescent objects can be captivating, with
their lustrous colors that shift as the object
moves.
You can see iridescence in butterfly wings.
And soap bubbles.

Scientists are interested in replicating the
iridescence that occurs in nature to make

brightly hued displays and color-shifting
paints without pigments.

When color arises from the structure of the
materials rather than their chemical makeup,
scientists call the effect structural color.

Researchers at Penn State and MIT developed
a way of harnessing structural color inspired

by a type of iridescence they saw in oil droplets
they were studying.

A similar effect appeared on the lid of a
petri dish they filled with warm water.
Maybe you’ve seen this effect, too.

When warm water sits in the dish, water vapor
condenses into droplets on the lid and produces
iridescent swirls.

Researchers wanted to understand what causes
those colorful displays.

At first the researchers thought the colors
might be a simple rainbow effect, caused when

spherical water droplets refract and scatter
sunlight into a range of colors.

But that didn’t quite add up with what they
were seeing.
Something else was going on.

And it was related to how light interacts
with the structure of the particular droplets
the scientists were studying.

Remember, they saw iridescence in water droplets
on a petri dish lid and in oil droplets.

Their oil droplets are made of two oils of
different densities that join together at
a curved interface.

That curved interface provides the right conditions
for a phenomenon called total internal reflection.

If the angle of the light rays entering the
droplet is just right, the light doesn’t
go straight through the droplet.

Instead it bounces off the concave interface
where the two oils meet.

All that bouncing means some light rays will
travel farther than others to reach your eyes.

That difference allows different wavelengths
within the rays to interfere with each other,

leading to colors that change based on viewing
angle.
Back to the petri dish.

The warm water droplets that condense on the
underside of the petri dish lid also create

total internal reflection at the concave interface
where the water droplet meets the air.

The color patterns we see depend on the size
and curvature of the droplets.

The researchers studied this effect further
by making different sizes of oil droplets
using a microfluidic device.

They could tune the curvature of that oil-oil
interface by adding surfactants to the water
bath.
And thus, they could control the colors.

They can even create patterns with a light-responsive
surfactant and a stencil.

The researchers modeled the iridescence produced
by their various types of droplets in three

dimensions—seen here on a plastic dome—to
better understand how the different variables
controlled the colorful displays.

Shin-Hyun Kim, who studies structural colors
at the Korea Advanced Institute of Science

and Technology, says this model potentially
provides a simple method for adding structural

color to various systems without requiring
delicate engineering of surfaces at the nanometer
scale.
